html:
For a Reuters live blog on U.S., UK and European stock markets, click LIVE/ or type LIVE/ in a news window

  • Zillow jumps on upbeat sales
  • Under Armour falls after margin warning

Updates with end of session

By Bansari Mayur Kamdar and Noel Randewich

Feb 11 (Reuters) - Wall Street stocks ended sharply lower on Friday for the second straight session, as investors fretted about deepening tensions between Russia and Ukraine.

Most of the 11 major S&P 500 sector indexes declined, led by technology .SPLRCT and consumer discretionary .SPLRCD. The energy sector index .SPNH surged as oil prices hit seven-year highs. (Full Story)

With investors already fretting about inflation and rising interest rates, selling on Wall Street accelerated after Washington warned that Russia had massed enough troops near Ukraine to launch a major invasion, and that an attack could begin any day. (Full Story)

"We just have to see how this plays out over the weekend and whether or not international leadership can bring this under wraps," said Thomas Hayes, managing member at Great Hill Capital LLC in New York. "If not, then the knock-on effects could be material, and that's what the markets is worried about."

Apple Inc AAPL.O, Amazon.com Inc AMZN.O, Nvidia Corp NVDA.O and Microsoft MSFT.O all fell, and weighed more than any others on the S&P 500's .SPX decline.

According to preliminary data, the S&P 500 .SPX lost 85.76 points, or 1.90%, to end at 4,418.32 points, while the Nasdaq Composite .IXIC lost 400.02 points, or 2.83%, to 13,784.13. The Dow Jones Industrial Average .DJI fell 510.12 points, or 1.45%, to 34,731.47.

The latest sell-off follows a slump on Thursday, when data showed consumer prices surged 7.5% in January, the biggest annual increase in 40 years. Comments from St. Louis Fed Bank President James Bullard about aggressive rate hikes have also rattled investor sentiment. (Full Story) (Full Story)

Traders are pricing in a half-point rate hike in March with just a scant chance of a smaller quarter-point raise, and heavy bets for a policy path that would bring rates to a range of 1.75%-2.00% by the end of the year. (Full Story) (Full Story)

A University of Michigan survey showed U.S. consumer sentiment fell to its lowest in more than a decade in early February on expectations that inflation would continue to rise in the near term. (Full Story)

The CBOE volatility index .VIX, also known as Wall Street's fear gauge, was up for a second straight session and hit its highest level since the end of January.

"The market volatility from January is not over and we expect continued choppiness as investors weigh the prospect of a more aggressive Federal Reserve in the face of rising inflation," said Richard Saperstein, chief investment officer, Treasury Partners.

Online real-estate platform Zillow Group Inc ZG.O jumped after beating Wall Street estimates for quarterly sales, boosted by an 11-fold revenue increase in its homes segment. (Full Story)

Under Armour Inc UAA.N slumped after warning that its profit margin would be under pressure in the current quarter. (Full Story)


(Reporting by Bansari Mayur Kamdar in Bengaluru and by Noel Randewich in Oakland, Calif.; Editing by Maju Samuel and Richard Chang)

(( noel.randewich@tr.com ; Twitter: https://twitter.com/randewich) )
